moves.1. e4: A rollicking good game, particularly for the psychological see-saw the game took me and my opponent (Matsumoto) into. We were both under great time pressure at the end of the game. The moves we made are sometimes not the best and we both missed our chances, but Hell ! what a rollicking good game that was !
moves.1... a6:
The St. George defense.
When an opponent plays something unusual , I ussually try to transpose the game into the openings i know. So, This move made me think .I thought for about 15 seconds and decided to avoid any plans that would involve a pin of black's Knight at c6 , also I couldn't use c4 for my bishop due to the threat of b5.
Moreover I ussually prefer to castle on the queenside with white, Now I should avoid that.
moves.2. Nc3: This move keeps my options open
moves.2... g6: Now black's plan is getting clearer. He wants to play on the dark central squares and He would castle on the Kingside.
moves.3. d4: Opposing black's plans on the dark squares
moves.4. f4: Re-exerting control over the dark squares by preventing e5
moves.4... Bg7 5. Nf3:
Both of us are staking claim on the dark squares.
We have now reached a position from the Robatsch defence/Pseudo-Austrian attack by transposition.
moves.5... Nd7:
Black's options here are
e6
f5
b5 (Book move - Robatsch defence)

However he deviated from the book with this Knight move. I don't think it is a bad move though as it 
a.Hits the central dark square e5
b.Keeps the option of c5 if needed
moves.6. Be3: I prevent c5 and I plan to exchange this bishop with the fianchettoed one by Qd2 and Bh6
moves.6... Ngf6 7. h3:
If I allow black to play Ng4 , he'd take my Bishop on e3 and I shall not be able to exchange it with Bg7. 
This move also allows me to start a pawnstorm to attack the black King after he castles. 

Chess engines rate any move available to my white Bishop at f1 better than this, but this was a blitz game and I loved the idea of a kingside pawn storm.
moves.7... O-O 8. Qd2: Consistent with my plan of exchanging his fianchettoed dark squared bishop my own dark squared bishop
moves.8... c5: Initially I had thought i wouldn't castle on the queenside because i was afraid of a pawnstorm there. But now I reflexively decided to do it  and have a go at the black king with a pawnstorm. I thought my pawns would bite faster than his.
moves.9. O-O-O: "Never attack till your Queen's rook has been activated" - Seigbert Tarrasch
moves.9... Qc7:
Question mark ? Black should start his own pawn storm against me before deciding where to place his queen.

I think black should have played either simply cxd4 (which would give his knight the option of coming to c4) or simply b5
moves.10. e5: I simply do not understand why I deviated from my plan of playing dxc5 followed by starting the pawn storm with g4. "Blitz - Bloody Hell !"
moves.10... Ne8:
Instead of this retreat cxd4 or Nh5 are better. Now my position is winning (and decisively so) !

moves.14. Nxd4:
And here it comes !
This piece sac and the few moves that follow it change the nature of the game and allow me to draw it
moves.14... exd4 15. Bxd4 Bxd4 16. Qxd4 Nef6 1:

moves.23. g4 Rf7 24. g5 Qe3+ 25. Kb1 Ng8 26. Q: Both of us were under huge time pressure here. So I decided to decrease the complications. I thought that a safe king and a passed h pawn will win me the game
